abstract_summ: Results suggest that immediate feedback from computer-based learning tasks benefit both high and low prior knowledge students, with low prior knowledge students exhibiting greater gains.We predict math performance using this non-math factor and show that it contributes novel explanatory value in modeling students’ learning behaviors.However, widespread use of adaptive math software in classrooms has not led to the expected changes in student achievement, particularly for racially minoritized students and students situated in poverty.Since it is well known in educational research that it is possible to observe a “Matthew Effect” in which the rich get richer, we wanted to see if feedback was useful for low prior knowledge students, as defined by students whose pretest score was at or below the median.Adaptive math software supports students’ learning by targeting specific math knowledge components.
